title: Election Day 2015: List of local measures
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Election Day 2015: List of local measures Election Day is November 3 in Oregon, and while it's not the most talked about election year, there are still important measures Oregonians will be deciding. Post to Facebook Election Day 2015: List of local measures Election Day is November 3 in Oregon, and while it's not the most talked about election year, there are still important measures Oregonians will be deciding.  //on.kgw.com/1RUEOFr   Election Day 2015: List of local measures KGW Staff 2:55 p.m. PDT October 20, 2015 ballot box vote oregon generic (Photo: KGW) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
PORTLAND, Ore. -- Election Day is November 3 in Oregon, and while it's not the most talked about election year, there are still important measures Oregonians will be deciding. 
Here's a look at what will be on local ballots: 
Washington County 
Measure No. 34-235 Shall Washington County support library services countywide by levying 22 cents per $1,000 assessed value for five years, beginning in 2016? This measure may cause property taxes to increase by more than three percent. 
Measure No. 34-236 Shall Washington County maintain public safety services by levying 42 cents per $1,000 assessed value for five years, beginning in 2016? This measure renews current local option taxes. 
Click here for more information on Washington County ballot measures, as well as city ballot measures. 
Multnomah County The City of Troutdale will be voting on a motor vehicle fuel tax. Riverdale School District voters will decide whether to pass a property tax to help fund school district operations. 
Click here for more information on the two measures. 
Clackamas County The cities of Milwaukie and West Linn will vote on a city council position. Canby voters will decide whether to pass a property tax to help fund the Canby fire department. Wilsonville voters will decide whether to form a coffee creek urban renewal district. Damascus voters will decide whether to approve a change to government spending limitations. Gladstone voters will decide whether the city should incur a debt to finance new city hall building and a new police station. Riverdale School District voters will decide whether to pass a property tax to help fund school district operations.
